description: Creates and executes a batch from an uploaded file of requests

completion_window.description: The time frame within which the batch should be processed. Currently only `24h` is supported.

endpoint.description: The endpoint to be used for all requests in the batch. Currently `/v1/responses`, `/v1/chat/completions`, `/v1/embeddings`, and `/v1/completions` are supported. Note that `/v1/embeddings` batches are also restricted to a maximum of 50,000 embedding inputs across all requests in the batch.

input_file_id.description:
The ID of an uploaded file that contains requests for the new batch.

See [upload file](https://platform.openai.com/docs/api-reference/files/create) for how to upload a file.

Your input file must be formatted as a [JSONL file](https://platform.openai.com/docs/api-reference/batch/request-input), and must be uploaded with the purpose `batch`. The file can contain up to 50,000 requests, and can be up to 200 MB in size.

anyOf.description:
Set of 16 key-value pairs that can be attached to an object. This can be
useful for storing additional information about the object in a structured
format, and querying for objects via API or the dashboard.

Keys are strings with a maximum length of 64 characters. Values are strings
with a maximum length of 512 characters.

output_expires_after.description: The expiration policy for the output and/or error file that are generated for a batch.

anchor.description: Anchor timestamp after which the expiration policy applies. Supported anchors: `created_at`. Note that the anchor is the file creation time, not the time the batch is created.

seconds.description: The number of seconds after the anchor time that the file will expire. Must be between 3600 (1 hour) and 2592000 (30 days).

output_expires_after.title: File expiration policy

cancelled_at.description: The Unix timestamp (in seconds) for when the batch was cancelled.

cancelling_at.description: The Unix timestamp (in seconds) for when the batch started cancelling.

completed_at.description: The Unix timestamp (in seconds) for when the batch was completed.

completion_window.description: The time frame within which the batch should be processed.

created_at.description: The Unix timestamp (in seconds) for when the batch was created.

endpoint.description: The OpenAI API endpoint used by the batch.

error_file_id.description: The ID of the file containing the outputs of requests with errors.

code.description: An error code identifying the error type.

anyOf.description: The line number of the input file where the error occurred, if applicable.

message.description: A human-readable message providing more details about the error.

anyOf.description: The name of the parameter that caused the error, if applicable.

object.description: The object type, which is always `list`.

expired_at.description: The Unix timestamp (in seconds) for when the batch expired.

expires_at.description: The Unix timestamp (in seconds) for when the batch will expire.

failed_at.description: The Unix timestamp (in seconds) for when the batch failed.

finalizing_at.description: The Unix timestamp (in seconds) for when the batch started finalizing.

in_progress_at.description: The Unix timestamp (in seconds) for when the batch started processing.

input_file_id.description: The ID of the input file for the batch.

anyOf.description:
Set of 16 key-value pairs that can be attached to an object. This can be
useful for storing additional information about the object in a structured
format, and querying for objects via API or the dashboard.

Keys are strings with a maximum length of 64 characters. Values are strings
with a maximum length of 512 characters.

model.description:
Model ID used to process the batch, like `gpt-5-2025-08-07`. OpenAI
offers a wide range of models with different capabilities, performance
characteristics, and price points. Refer to the [model
guide](https://platform.openai.com/docs/models) to browse and compare available models.

object.description: The object type, which is always `batch`.

output_file_id.description: The ID of the file containing the outputs of successfully executed requests.

request_counts.description: The request counts for different statuses within the batch.

completed.description: Number of requests that have been completed successfully.

failed.description: Number of requests that have failed.

total.description: Total number of requests in the batch.

status.description: The current status of the batch.

usage.description:
Represents token usage details including input tokens, output tokens, a
breakdown of output tokens, and the total tokens used. Only populated on
batches created after September 7, 2025.

input_tokens_details.description: A detailed breakdown of the input tokens.

cached_tokens.description:
The number of tokens that were retrieved from the cache. [More on
prompt caching](https://platform.openai.com/docs/guides/prompt-caching).

output_tokens_details.description: A detailed breakdown of the output tokens.

total_tokens.description: The total number of tokens used.
